FedADMM-InSa: An Inexact and Self-Adaptive ADMM for Federated Learning

Yongcun Song  Ziqi Wang  Enrique Zuazua Chair for Dynamics, Control, Machine Learning and Numerics – Alexander von Humboldt Professorship, Department of Mathematics, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, Cauerstrasse 11, 91058 Erlangen, Germany. Email: yongcun.song@fau.de.Corresponding author. Chair for Dynamics, Control, Machine Learning and Numerics – Alexander von Humboldt Professorship, Department of Mathematics, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, Cauerstrasse 11, 91058 Erlangen, Germany. Email: ziqi.wang@fau.de.Chair for Dynamics, Control, Machine Learning and Numerics – Alexander von Humboldt Professorship, Department of Mathematics, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, Cauerstrasse 11, 91058 Erlangen, Germany. Chair of Computational Mathematics, Fundación Deusto, Avda. de las Universidades, 24, 48007 Bilbao, Basque Country, Spain. Departamento de Matemáticas, Universidad Autónoma de Madrid, 28049 Madrid, Spain. Email: enrique.zuazua@fau.de.

Abstract. Federated learning (FL) is a promising framework for learning from distributed data while maintaining privacy. The development of efficient FL algorithms encounters various challenges, including heterogeneous data and systems, limited communication capacities, and constrained local computational resources. Recently developed FedADMM methods show great resilience to both data and system heterogeneity. However, they still suffer from performance deterioration if the hyperparameters are not carefully tuned. To address this issue, we propose an inexact and self-adaptive FedADMM algorithm, termed FedADMM-InSa. First, we design an inexactness criterion for the clients’ local updates to eliminate the need for empirically setting the local training accuracy. This inexactness criterion can be assessed by each client independently based on its unique condition, thereby reducing the local computational cost and mitigating the undesirable straggle effect. The convergence of the resulting inexact ADMM is proved under the assumption of strongly convex loss functions. Additionally, we present a self-adaptive scheme that dynamically adjusts each client’s penalty parameter, enhancing algorithm robustness by mitigating the need for empirical penalty parameter choices for each client. Extensive numerical experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets are conducted. As validated by some numerical tests, our proposed algorithm can reduce the clients’ local computational load significantly and also accelerate the learning process compared to the vanilla FedADMM.

1 Introduction

With the increasing volume of data generated by massively distributed devices and organizations, traditional centralized deep learning paradigms encounter challenges in terms of data collection, privacy concerns, and scalability. To address the above challenges, federated learning (FL) [21, 22, 26] has emerged as a promising paradigm and has gained significant attention in recent years.

In FL, multiple clients (devices) in a distributed environment collaboratively train a neural network model under the coordination of a central server, without centralizing their data. The training process of FL consists of several communication rounds. For example, in the most commonly used FedAvg [26] algorithm, at every communication round, each client computes a model update on its local data using the latest copy of the global model parameters and then sends the model update to the central server. The server aggregates these updates by averaging to update the global model parameters, which are then sent to all clients. Despite the fact that no raw data is transmitted, there is still a risk of privacy breaches, such as data reconstruction attacks [7, 34, 35, 37].

One of the key properties of FL is that the clients are massively distributed and have limited communication capacity [18, 26, 40]. To decrease the number of communication rounds needed to train a model, FedAvg suggests increasing local computation on each client. Unlike traditional distributed optimization [43] where consensus is performed after every local gradient computation, in FedAvg, the clients perform multiple full-batch or stochastic gradient descent steps before these local model parameters are aggregated in order to update the global model parameters.

However, simply increasing local gradient descent steps as in FedAvg would cause the client drift [19] issue due to the inherent data and system heterogeneity in FL [18, 26]. The client drift issue comes from the fact that clients in FL normally possess unbalanced and non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) local datasets, which leads to inconsistent minima of the local and global objective functions [19, 32]. As a result, the aggregated global model suffers from deviation and does not converge to its true optimum [24]. To address this, FedProx [23] was proposed by adding an extra proximal term to the client’s loss function to constrain the client’s local model to be close to the server’s global model. However, the extra proximal term might degrade the training performance unless carefully tuned [31]. In [19], a method called Scaffold is proposed to reduce client drift by using variance reduction to correct each client’s local updates. However, this method doubles the size of variables that need to be communicated between the server and clients, which is not ideal given the limited communication resources in FL.

Recent findings show that FedADMM methods [1, 13, 33, 41, 42] based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) [4, 9] are inherently resilient to heterogeneous clients in FL. FedADMM leverages dual variables to tackle statistical heterogeneity and accommodates system heterogeneity by tolerating variable amounts of work performed by clients. FedADMM maintains identical communication costs per round as FedAvg/Prox and generalizes them using the augmented Lagrangian with dual variables and an extra quadratic penalty term as the client’s local loss function. This modification strikes a balance between updating the client’s local model and staying consistent with the global model [13].

Despite the above-mentioned nice features, current FedADMM methods still suffer from performance deterioration and the straggler effect [18, 30] if the hyperparameters are not carefully tuned, especially the amount of local training workload and the choice of the penalty parameter. In particular, FedADMM methods require clients to perform a certain amount of local training workload, which corresponds to solving the ADMM subproblem inexactly. This is implemented empirically by either commanding clients to solve the subproblem to a constant given accuracy [13, 41, 42] or performing a fixed number of (stochastic) gradient descent steps [1, 33]. However, the accuracy of this solution significantly impacts the effectiveness of the algorithm [11]. Meanwhile, empirically assigning the same amount of local training workload overlooks the heterogeneity in clients’ data and systems (e.g., non-IID datasets and varying computational resources). This oversight may also cause a severe straggler effect, as waiting for the resource-constrained clients to finish the overload work will slow down the training process, and simply dropping them will lead to a biased global model [3, 42]. Another critical issue involves the selection of the penalty parameter of the quadratic term in the augmented Lagrangian functions. It has been shown in ADMM applications [14, 28, 36] that the efficiency of ADMM heavily depends on the penalty parameter. If the penalty parameter is chosen too small or too large, the solution time can increase significantly. The problem is more complicated in FedADMM as each client can use a different penalty parameter, and an inappropriate choice of the penalty parameter can potentially deteriorate the performance of FedADMM methods.

To address the aforementioned issues, we propose an inexact and self-adaptive FedADMM algorithm, referred to as FedADMM-InSa. Firstly, we introduce an easy-to-implement and adaptive inexactness criterion to guide the client’s local training. Our approach eliminates the need to manually set gradient descent steps or predefine a constant accuracy. This provides each client with the flexibility to solve its subproblem inexactly based on its unique situation, thereby eliminating the potential straggler effect. Furthermore, we design a scheme to dynamically adjust each client’s penalty parameter based on the discrepancy between its local model parameters and the global model parameters, avoiding unexpected performance deterioration due to improperly chosen fixed penalty parameters.

Overall, our main contributions are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose an inexactness criterion that enables each client to dynamically adjust the precision of local training in each communication round. There is no need to empirically set the number of gradient descent steps or perceived constant accuracy a priori. This flexibility allows our algorithm to better adapt to the heterogeneous clients and datasets, save local computational resources, and mitigate the straggler effect.

  2. 2.

    We develop a self-adaptive scheme for adjusting each client’s penalty parameter. The scheme dynamically balances the primal and dual residuals defined by the dissimilarity between the client’s local parameters and the server’s global parameters between two communication rounds. This adaptive scheme significantly enhances the robustness of our algorithm and eliminates the risk associated with selecting inappropriate penalty parameters for individual clients.

  3. 3.

    The convergence of our proposed algorithm using the inexactness criterion is analyzed. Extensive numerical experiments demonstrate the improved performance of our proposed inexactness criterion and self-adaptive penalty adjusting scheme. As validated by some numerical tests, our proposed algorithm reduces the clients’ local computational load by 64.3% while accelerating the learning process when compared to the vanilla FedADMM.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we first provide a brief background on FL and ADMM, then the vanilla application of ADMM in FL and the resulting FedADMM algorithm. Section 3 presents our proposed FedADMM-InSa method, including the inexactness criterion and the self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme. The experimental setup and simulation results are presented in Section 4. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 5 and provide more technical details in Appendix A.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we briefly introduce the mathematical formulation of FL and ADMM, which are central subjects of the study in this paper.

2.1 Federated Learning

Mathematically, the training process of horizontal FL can be formulated as the following minimization problem:

where m𝑚m is the number of clients, z∈ℝn𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛z\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is the trainable parameters, fi:ℝn→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is the local loss function of each client i∈[m]≔{1,…,m}𝑖delimited-[]𝑚≔1…𝑚i\in[m]\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,m\}, αi>0subscript𝛼𝑖0\alpha_{i}>0 is the weight coefficient assigned to client i𝑖i by the server, and ∑i=1mαi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}=1. A common choice is αi=Ni/Nsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖𝑁\alpha_{i}=N_{i}/N, where Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} is client i𝑖i’s data volume and N=∑i=1mNi𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑁𝑖N=\sum_{i=1}^{m}N_{i}, i.e., weighting clients proportionally to their data volumes.

2.2 ADMM

Lβ​(x,y,λ)=θ1​(x)+θ2​(y)−λT​(A​x+B​y−b)+β2​‖A​x+B​y−b‖2,subscript𝐿𝛽𝑥𝑦𝜆subscript𝜃1𝑥subscript𝜃2𝑦superscript𝜆𝑇𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑏𝛽2superscriptnorm𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑏2L_{\beta}(x,y,\lambda)=\theta_{1}(x)+\theta_{2}(y)-\lambda^{T}(Ax+By-b)+\frac{\beta}{2}\|Ax+By-b\|^{2}, (2.3)

where λ∈ℝn3𝜆superscriptℝsubscript𝑛3\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{3}} is the Lagrangian multiplier associated with the equality constraint in (2.2), and β>0𝛽0\beta>0 is a penalty parameter. Here and henceforth, we denote by ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| the Euclidean (or ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-) norm.

Then, starting with an initial point {y0,λ0}superscript𝑦0superscript𝜆0\{y^{0},\lambda^{0}\}, for k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0, the ADMM [9] iteratively updates the variables {x,y,λ}𝑥𝑦𝜆\left\{x,y,\lambda\right\} in the following way:

xk+1=arg⁡minx∈ℝn1⁡Lβ​(x,yk,λk),superscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑥superscriptℝsubscript𝑛1subscript𝐿𝛽𝑥superscript𝑦𝑘superscript𝜆𝑘\displaystyle x^{k+1}=\arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}}L_{\beta}\left(x,y^{k},\lambda^{k}\right), (2.4a)
yk+1=arg⁡miny∈ℝn2⁡Lβ​(xk+1,y,λk),superscript𝑦𝑘1subscript𝑦superscriptℝsubscript𝑛2subscript𝐿𝛽superscript𝑥𝑘1𝑦superscript𝜆𝑘\displaystyle y^{k+1}=\arg\min_{y\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}}L_{\beta}\left(x^{k+1},y,\lambda^{k}\right), (2.4b)
λk+1=λk−β​(A​xk+1+B​yk+1−b).superscript𝜆𝑘1superscript𝜆𝑘𝛽𝐴superscript𝑥𝑘1𝐵superscript𝑦𝑘1𝑏\displaystyle\lambda^{k+1}=\lambda^{k}-\beta\left(Ax^{k+1}+By^{k+1}-b\right). (2.4c)

The ADMM is a variant of the classic augmented Lagrangian method (ALM) [17, 27], where the subproblem of each ALM iteration is decomposed into two parts and then solved in a Gauss-Seidel manner. The ADMM possesses a distinct advantage as the decomposed subproblems are typically much easier than those encountered in the ALM, allowing for the exploitation of inherent properties and structures within the model under investigation. Moreover, the ADMM usually exhibits satisfactory numerical performance without the need for specific initial iterates. These characteristics make the ADMM a benchmark algorithm across various domains, including image processing [15], statistical learning [12, 38], and optimal control problems [10, 11, 29, 39], etc. For a more comprehensive understanding of the ADMM, one can refer to [4, 8].

2.3 Vanilla FedADMM

In this subsection, we present the application of ADMM in the context of FL, leading to the derivation of the vanilla FedADMM [42]. Subsequently, we systematically analyze the challenges and limitations associated with each iterative step of the vanilla FedADMM.

To apply the ADMM to address the FL problem (2.1), we first introduce auxiliary variables ui=zsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑧u_{i}=z, i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]mi\in[\mathrm{m}], and rewrite problem (2.1) into the following consensus setting:

minui,z∈ℝn​∑i=1mαi​fi​(ui), s.t. ​ui=z,∀i∈[m].formulae-sequencesubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖 s.t. subscript𝑢𝑖𝑧for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\min_{u_{i},z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}f_{i}(u_{i}),\text{ s.t. }u_{i}=z,\forall i\in[m]. (2.5)

It is clear that problem (2.5) is equivalent to (2.1) in the sense that their optimal solutions coincide. The formulation of problem (2.5) naturally fits into the FL setting, where ui∈ℝnsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛u_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} can be interpreted as the local model parameters held by client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], and z∈ℝn𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛z\in\mathbb{R}^{n} as the global model parameters held by the server. Therefore, in the following discussions, we concentrate on solving the optimization problem (2.5) instead of (2.1), as they are equivalent.

Then, given an initial point {z0,λ0}superscript𝑧0superscript𝜆0\{z^{0},\lambda^{0}\}, for k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0, we can have the vanilla FedADMM that iteratively updates the variables {u,λ,z}𝑢𝜆𝑧\left\{u,\lambda,z\right\} in the following steps:

As seen above, these iterative updates naturally suit the FL setting. The updates of uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} in (2.8a) and λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\lambda_{i}^{k+1} in (2.8b) represent client i𝑖i’s local update process, and can be performed in parallel by each client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]. Meanwhile, the update of zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1} in (2.8c) is the server aggregation process after receiving uk+1superscript𝑢𝑘1u^{k+1}, λk+1superscript𝜆𝑘1\lambda^{k+1}, and β𝛽\beta from the clients. We then take a closer look at the solutions of the subproblems (2.8a) - (2.8c) and analyze the associated difficulties and limitations.

2.3.1 Client’s Local Update: Subproblems (2.8a) and (2.8b)

The u𝑢u-subproblem (2.8a) and the λ𝜆\lambda-subproblem (2.8b) correspond to the client’s local update process and can be performed in parallel. The λ𝜆\lambda-subproblem (2.8b) is simple and has an analytical form. However, the u𝑢u-subproblem (2.8a) is challenging due to the use of high-dimensional and nonlinear neural networks (such as the ResNets [16]) in FL. It generally lacks a closed-form solution. As a result, the subproblem (2.8a) should be solved iteratively and inexactly, and the implementation of the FedADMM (2.8) must be embedded by an internal iterative process for the subproblem (2.8a)

In the vanilla FedADMM method, the clients normally use gradient-based methods for solving (2.8a) to a certain precision. For example, client i𝑖i can implement a prescribed number of E𝐸E steps of the full-batch gradient descent as follows:

uik,e+1=uik,e−ηi​∇uiLβi​(uik,e,λik,zk),e=0,1,…,E−1,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑒1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑒subscript𝜂𝑖subscript∇subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝐿subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑒superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘𝑒01…𝐸1u_{i}^{k,e+1}=u_{i}^{k,e}-\eta_{i}\nabla_{u_{i}}L_{\beta_{i}}\left(u_{i}^{k,e},\lambda_{i}^{k},z^{k}\right),\quad e=0,1,\ldots,E-1, (2.9)

where ηi>0subscript𝜂𝑖0\eta_{i}>0 is the learning rate (also known as the step size). Then, client i𝑖i sets uik+1≔uik,E≔superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝐸u_{i}^{k+1}\coloneqq u_{i}^{k,E} and uses it to update λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\lambda_{i}^{k+1} by (2.8b). While other optimization schemes like stochastic gradient descent and quasi-Newton methods such as L-BFGS [25] are plausible, the accuracy of this inexact solution significantly influences the algorithm’s effectiveness [11]. A notable mathematical problem arises concerning the determination of an appropriate inexactness criterion for solving the subproblem (2.8a) inexactly.

Current FedADMM methods often require an empirically perceived precision in advance. For instance, clients may be instructed to perform a fixed number of (stochastic) gradient descent steps [1, 33] or solve the subproblem up to a constant predefined accuracy [13, 41, 42]. However, empirically assigning the same amount of local training workload is not a good strategy for heterogeneous clients with non-IID data and varying computational resources. For instance, assigning too much workload may inefficiently utilize local computational resources and cause a severe straggler effect, especially among clients with limited computational resources. Moreover, there is no necessity to pursue excessively accurate solutions for (2.8a), particularly when the iterates are still far from the solution point. Additionally, current FedADMM methods employ a fixed penalty parameter β𝛽\beta throughout the training process, without considering the heterogeneity of clients in FL. If the penalty parameter is inappropriately chosen at the beginning, the method’s efficiency and performance would deteriorate without remedy.

To tackle the above-mentioned issues, we design a readily implementable and appropriately accurate inexactness criterion for solving subproblem (2.8a) and a self-adaptive scheme to adjust each client’s penalty parameter βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} in Section 3. As a result, an inexact and self-adaptive FedADMM is proposed, enabling clients to dynamically adjust local training precision each round, eliminating the need to preset accuracy. This flexibility enhances the adaptability of our algorithm to diverse clients and datasets, saves local computational resources, and mitigates the straggler effect. In addition, the self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme improves the robustness of our algorithm by eliminating the risk associated with inappropriate pre-selection of clients’ penalty parameters.

2.3.2 Server’s Aggregation: Subproblem (2.8c)

The z𝑧z-subproblem (2.8c) is addressed by the server to update the global parameter zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1}. It follows from (2.6) that

Lα,β​(uk+1,λk+1,z)=∑i=1mαi​(fi​(uik+1)−(λik+1)⊤​(uik+1−z)+βi2​‖uik+1−z‖2),subscript𝐿𝛼𝛽superscript𝑢𝑘1superscript𝜆𝑘1𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1topsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1𝑧subscript𝛽𝑖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1𝑧2L_{\alpha,\beta}\left(u^{k+1},\lambda^{k+1},z\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\alpha_{i}}\left(f_{i}(u_{i}^{k+1})-(\lambda_{i}^{k+1})^{\top}(u_{i}^{k+1}-z)+\frac{\beta_{i}}{2}\|u_{i}^{k+1}-z\|^{2}\right), (2.10)

which implies that

zk+1=arg⁡minz∈ℝn​∑i=1mαi​((λik+1)⊤​z+βi2​‖uik+1−z‖2).superscript𝑧𝑘1subscript𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1top𝑧subscript𝛽𝑖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1𝑧2z^{k+1}=\arg\min_{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\alpha_{i}}\left((\lambda_{i}^{k+1})^{\top}z+\frac{\beta_{i}}{2}\|u_{i}^{k+1}-z\|^{2}\right). (2.11)

Hence, zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1} has an analytical form given by

zk+1=1∑i=1mαi​βi​∑i=1mαi​(βi​uik+1−λik+1).superscript𝑧𝑘11superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1z^{k+1}=\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\alpha_{i}}\beta_{i}}\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\alpha_{i}}\left(\beta_{i}u_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k+1}\right). (2.12)

The server can also incorporate the partial client participation strategy by selecting a subset of clients ℳk⊆[m]superscriptℳ𝑘delimited-[]𝑚\mathcal{M}^{k}\subseteq[m] to calculate updated parameters uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} and λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\lambda_{i}^{k+1} using (2.8a) and (2.8b) at the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-th communication round. Note from (2.12) that the clients can provide the server with calculated (βi​uik+1−λik+1)subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1(\beta_{i}u_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k+1}) instead of uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} and λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\lambda_{i}^{k+1}, thereby reducing the communication cost. Meanwhile, for the unselected clients i∉ℳk𝑖superscriptℳ𝑘i\notin\mathcal{M}^{k}, the server can simply use their previously communicated local model parameters by setting uik+1≔uik≔superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘u_{i}^{k+1}\coloneqq u_{i}^{k} and λik+1≔λik≔superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘\lambda_{i}^{k+1}\coloneqq\lambda_{i}^{k}. Finally, after receiving updated parameters (βi​uik+1−λik+1)subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1(\beta_{i}u_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k+1}) and βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} from the clients, the server can get the updated global model parameters zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1} by (2.12).

With the above analysis of the client update and the server aggregation processes, we summarize the vanilla FedADMM algorithm based on (2.8) in Algorithm 1.

3 An Inexact and Self-Adaptive FedADMM

In this section, we present the design of our inexact and self-adaptive FedADMM algorithm. We first present a refined server update approach with improved stability. Then, we design an inexactness criterion for solving (2.8a) and a self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme to update β𝛽\beta. We further show that the inexactness criterion and the self-adaptive scheme can be combined with each other.

3.1 Server’s Aggregation with Memory

From (2.12), it is evident that in the vanilla FedADMM, the update of the server’s global model parameters zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1} depends solely on the local parameters updated by clients in the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-th communication round. Due to the uncertainty arising from heterogeneous local updates, the global model parameters may undergo significant fluctuations. To address this challenge, we draw inspiration from exponential moving average methods used in several fields (see e.g., [2, 5, 6]) and propose an improved method for updating global model parameters zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1z^{k+1} as follows:

z^k+1superscript^𝑧𝑘1\displaystyle\hat{z}^{k+1} =1∑i=1mαi​βi​∑i=1mαi​(βi​uik+1−λik+1),absent1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}\left(\beta_{i}u_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k+1}\right), (3.1a)
zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1\displaystyle z^{k+1} =11+δ​z^k+1+δ1+δ​zk,absent11𝛿superscript^𝑧𝑘1𝛿1𝛿superscript𝑧𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{1}{1+\delta}\hat{z}^{k+1}+\frac{\delta}{1+\delta}z^{k}, (3.1b)

where δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 controls the trade-off between stability and responsiveness in the server update process.

The proposed server update strategy (3.1) improves the stability of aggregation by balancing the current and previous global model parameters. This ensures the robustness of the global model in the face of variable clients’ local updates. On the one hand, it allows for the memorization of zksuperscript𝑧𝑘z^{k}, thereby minimizing the sensitivity to outliers and leading to a more stable global model. On the other hand, the strategy maintains adaptability to the changing z^k+1superscript^𝑧𝑘1\hat{z}^{k+1}, ensuring that the global model responds appropriately to evolving local updates.

Meanwhile, the proposed server update strategy (3.1) can be interpreted by augmenting the vanilla z𝑧z-subproblem (2.8c) with an additional proximal term, given by

zk+1=arg⁡minz∈ℝn⁡Lα,β​(uk+1,λk+1,z)+δ2​∑i=1mαi​βi​‖z−zk‖2.superscript𝑧𝑘1subscript𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝐿𝛼𝛽superscript𝑢𝑘1superscript𝜆𝑘1𝑧𝛿2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptnorm𝑧superscript𝑧𝑘2z^{k+1}=\arg\min_{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\ L_{\alpha,\beta}\left(u^{k+1},\lambda^{k+1},z\right)+\frac{\delta}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}\|z-z^{k}\|^{2}. (3.2)

3.2 An Inexact Version of FedADMM

In this subsection, we propose an inexactness criterion for solving (2.8a) to address the challenges of presetting the client’s local update precision.

Inexactness criterion of (2.8a).

We first start with analyzing the optimality condition of the u𝑢u-subproblem (2.8a). From (2.6), we have

Lβi​(ui,λik,zk)=fi​(ui)−(λik)⊤​(ui−zk)+βi2​‖ui−zk‖2,subscript𝐿subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘topsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝛽𝑖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝑧𝑘2L_{\beta_{i}}\left(u_{i},\lambda_{i}^{k},z^{k}\right)=f_{i}(u_{i})-(\lambda_{i}^{k})^{\top}(u_{i}-z^{k})+\frac{\beta_{i}}{2}\|u_{i}-z^{k}\|^{2}, (3.3)

and accordingly

∇uiLβi​(ui,λik,zk)=∇fi​(ui)−λik+βi​(ui−zk).subscript∇subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝐿subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝑧𝑘\nabla_{u_{i}}L_{\beta_{i}}\left(u_{i},\lambda_{i}^{k},z^{k}\right)=\nabla f_{i}(u_{i})-\lambda_{i}^{k}+\beta_{i}\left(u_{i}-z^{k}\right). (3.4)

Let uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} be a solution of the subproblem (2.8a), then, it satisfies

∇fi​(uik+1)−λik+βi​(uik+1−zk)=0.∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑧𝑘0\nabla f_{i}(u_{i}^{k+1})-\lambda_{i}^{k}+\beta_{i}\left(u_{i}^{k+1}-z^{k}\right)=0. (3.5)

Based on the optimality condition (3.5), for each client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], we define eik​(ui)superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}) as

eik​(ui)=∇fi​(ui)−λik+βi​(ui−zk).superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝑧𝑘e_{i}^{k}(u_{i})=\nabla f_{i}(u_{i})-\lambda_{i}^{k}+\beta_{i}\left(u_{i}-z^{k}\right). (3.6)

It is clear that a solution uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} of the u𝑢u-subproblem (2.8a) at the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-th iteration satisfies eik​(uik+1)=0superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘10e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k+1})=0. Hence, we can use eik​(ui)superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}) as the residual for the u𝑢u-subproblem. With the help of eik​(ui)superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}), we propose the following inexactness criterion. For each client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], at the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-th iteration, it computes uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} such that

‖eik​(uik+1)‖≤σi​‖eik​(uik)‖,normsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1subscript𝜎𝑖normsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘\left\|e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k+1})\right\|\leq\sigma_{i}\left\|e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k})\right\|, (3.7)

where σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} is a given constant satisfying

0<σi<2​ci2​ci+βi<1,0subscript𝜎𝑖2subscript𝑐𝑖2subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖10<\sigma_{i}<\frac{\sqrt{2c_{i}}}{\sqrt{2c_{i}}+\sqrt{\beta_{i}}}<1, (3.8)

and ci>0subscript𝑐𝑖0c_{i}>0 is a parameter associated with the strong convexity constant of client i𝑖i’s loss function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, i.e., (∇fi​(x)−∇fi​(y))⊤​(x−y)≥ci​‖x−y‖2,∀x,y∈ℝnformulae-sequencesuperscript∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑦top𝑥𝑦subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛(\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(y))^{\top}(x-y)\geq c_{i}\|x-y\|^{2},\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. Equivalently, the condition (3.8) can be written as

0<σi<22+β~i<1,0subscript𝜎𝑖22subscript~𝛽𝑖10<\sigma_{i}<\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{\tilde{\beta}_{i}}}<1, (3.9)

where β~i=βi/cisubscript~𝛽𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖\tilde{\beta}_{i}={\beta_{i}}/{c_{i}}. It is evident that a smaller β~isubscript~𝛽𝑖\tilde{\beta}_{i} leads to a higher permissible value of σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}, indicating that the subproblem can be solved with less precision. In practical scenarios, each client can (locally) convexify its local loss function by incorporating a regularization term. Our inexactness criterion can also be applied to the non-convex problems by using a βi~>0~subscript𝛽𝑖0\tilde{\beta_{i}}>0 in (3.9). Subsequent numerical experiments in Section 4, covering both strongly convex and non-convex problems, also underscore the feasibility of our inexactness criterion (3.7).

It is noteworthy that our inexactness criterion can be assessed by each client autonomously based on its present model and penalty parameter, and it can be seamlessly executed during iterations. There is no requirement to predefine any empirically perceived constant accuracy. This gives each client the flexibility to solve its subproblem inexactly, aligning with its distinct non-IID data and computational resources. Consequently, this approach effectively mitigates the potential risk of the straggler effect that may arise with resource-constrained clients. Overall, these attributes make the inexactness criterion (3.7) straightforward to implement and more likely to result in local computational savings.

FedADMM-In: An inexact FedADMM algorithm.

Based on the discussions above, the iterative three steps of FedADMM with the inexactness criterion (3.7) are given by

uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle u_{i}^{k+1} ≈arg⁡minui∈ℝn⁡Lβi​(ui,λik,zk),∀i∈[m],formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝐿subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle\approx\arg\min_{u_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}L_{\beta_{i}}\left(u_{i},\lambda_{i}^{k},z^{k}\right),\forall i\in[m], (3.10a)
λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle\lambda_{i}^{k+1} =λik−βi​(uik+1−zk),∀i∈[m],formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑧𝑘for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle=\lambda_{i}^{k}-\beta_{i}\left(u_{i}^{k+1}-z^{k}\right),\forall i\in[m], (3.10b)
zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1\displaystyle z^{k+1} =arg⁡minz∈ℝn⁡Lα,β​(uk+1,λk+1,z)+δ2​∑i=1mαi​βi​‖z−zk‖2.absentsubscript𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝐿𝛼𝛽superscript𝑢𝑘1superscript𝜆𝑘1𝑧𝛿2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptnorm𝑧superscript𝑧𝑘2\displaystyle=\arg\min_{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\ L_{\alpha,\beta}\left(u^{k+1},\lambda^{k+1},z\right)+\frac{\delta}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}\|z-z^{k}\|^{2}. (3.10c)

We denote by FedADMM-In the FedADMM algorithm with the inexactness criterion (3.7) and summarize it in Algorithm 2.

Convergence analysis.

Let us analyze the convergence of our proposed FedADMM-In algorithm under the following assumptions:

Assumption 3.1.

For all i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], the gradient of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}-Lipschitz, that is,

‖∇fi​(x)−∇fi​(y)‖≤si​‖x−y‖,si>0,∀x,y∈ℝn.formulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑦subscript𝑠𝑖norm𝑥𝑦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑖0for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(y)\right\|\leq s_{i}\|x-y\|,s_{i}>0,\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. (3.11)
Assumption 3.2.

For all i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}-strongly convex, that is,

(∇fi​(x)−∇fi​(y))⊤​(x−y)≥ci​‖x−y‖2,ci>0,∀x,y∈ℝn.formulae-sequencesuperscript∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑦top𝑥𝑦subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑖0for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛(\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(y))^{\top}(x-y)\geq c_{i}\|x-y\|^{2},c_{i}>0,\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. (3.12)

From the strong convexity assumption, it is easy to deduce that problem (2.1) has a unique solution, denoted by z∗superscript𝑧z^{*}. As a consequence, problem (2.5), which is equivalent to (2.1), also has a unique solution (u∗,z∗)superscript𝑢superscript𝑧(u^{*},z^{*}), where ui∗=z∗,∀i∈[m]formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝑧for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚u_{i}^{*}=z^{*},\forall i\in[m]. On the other hand, from the above assumptions, the dual problem of problem (2.5) has a unique solution λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} and the strong duality holds. In the following Theorem 3.3, we show that the sequence generated by iterative scheme (3.10) (i.e., Algorithm 2 with full client participation) converges to (u∗,λ∗,z∗)superscript𝑢superscript𝜆superscript𝑧(u^{*},\lambda^{*},z^{*}).

Theorem 3.3.

Let {wk}={(uk,λk,zk)⊤}superscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsuperscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝜆𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘top\{w^{k}\}=\{(u^{k},\lambda^{k},z^{k})^{\top}\} be the sequence generated by iterative scheme (3.10) (i.e., Algorithm 2 with full client participation). Then, we have the following assertions:

‖eik​(uik+1)‖⟶k→∞0,uik⟶k→∞ui∗,λik⟶k→∞λi∗,zk⟶k→∞z∗,∀i∈[m].formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘normsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘10formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘superscript𝑧for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\|e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k+1})\|\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0,\quad u_{i}^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}u_{i}^{*},\quad\lambda_{i}^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}\lambda_{i}^{*},\quad z^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}z^{*},\quad\forall i\in[m]. (3.13)

The detailed proof is presented in Appendix A.1, which is inspired by [11, Sec. 3.3]. Although the convergence proof is conducted under the strong convexity assumption, our algorithm with the proposed inexactness criterion can also be applied to the non-convex cases by using a βi~>0~subscript𝛽𝑖0\tilde{\beta_{i}}>0 in (3.9). Moreover, the effectiveness of the algorithm with partial client participation in both strongly convex and non-convex cases is validated by the numerical experiments in Section 4.

Remark 3.4.

In practical applications, one can also use zksuperscript𝑧𝑘z^{k} instead of uiksuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘u_{i}^{k} on the right-hand side of the inexactness criterion (3.7). We empirically demonstrate in Section 4 that such a substitution improves the FL training performance in terms of improved model accuracy and reduced computational load. This substitution alleviates the unnecessary pursuit of the client’s local minima, which is normally inconsistent with the global minima due to the non-IID datasets. The convergence analysis of the algorithm employing this modified inexactness criterion and partial client participation serves as an interesting future study.

3.3 Self-Adaptive Penalty Parameter βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k}

In this subsection, we present a self-adaptive scheme for adjusting the penalty parameter βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} for client i𝑖i at communication round k𝑘k to further improve the performance of our FedADMM-In algorithm. This also makes the algorithm more robust to different initial choices of the penalty parameter.

Self-adaptive scheme.

As shown in (3.10), the FedADMM-In algorithm is an iterative algorithm, and an intuitive stopping criterion of the iterative updates can be uik+1−uik=0superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘0u_{i}^{k+1}-u_{i}^{k}=0 and λik+1−λik=0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘0\lambda_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k}=0. It follows from (3.10b) that λik+1−λik=0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘0\lambda_{i}^{k+1}-\lambda_{i}^{k}=0 implies that uik+1−zk=0superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑧𝑘0u_{i}^{k+1}-z^{k}=0. Inspired by the stopping criterion, we define the primal residual piksuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘p_{i}^{k} and the dual residual diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k} as follows:

piksuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘\displaystyle p_{i}^{k} =‖uik+1−uik‖,i∈[m],formulae-sequenceabsentnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle=\|u_{i}^{k+1}-u_{i}^{k}\|,\ i\in[m], (3.14a)
diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘\displaystyle d_{i}^{k} =‖uik+1−zk‖,i∈[m].formulae-sequenceabsentnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑧𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle=\|u_{i}^{k+1}-z^{k}\|,\ i\in[m]. (3.14b)

To adaptively update βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k}, we use the following scheme:

βik+1={βik​τ, if ​dik>μ​pik,βik/τ, if ​pik>μ​dik,βik, otherwise ,superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘1casessuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘𝜏 if superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘𝜏 if superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘 otherwise \beta_{i}^{k+1}=\begin{cases}\beta_{i}^{k}\tau,&\text{ if }d_{i}^{k}>\mu p_{i}^{k},\\ \beta_{i}^{k}/\tau,&\text{ if }p_{i}^{k}>\mu d_{i}^{k},\\ \beta_{i}^{k},&\text{ otherwise },\end{cases} (3.15)

where μ,τ>1𝜇𝜏1\mu,\tau>1 are parameters to choose, and a typical choice can be μ=20𝜇20\mu=20 and τ=2𝜏2\tau=2.

The essence of the self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme (3.15) lies in dynamically balancing the primal residual piksuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘p_{i}^{k} and the dual residual diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k}. For instance, dik>μ​piksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k}>\mu p_{i}^{k} indicates an excessive dual residual diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k}. Following the definition of diksuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘d_{i}^{k} in (3.14b), this suggests that client i𝑖i’s updated local model parameters uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} deviate significantly from the current global model parameters zksuperscript𝑧𝑘z^{k}. Consequently, client i𝑖i is prompted to increase its penalty parameter βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} to impose a more substantial penalty on the constraint. Conversely, a reduction in βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} is recommended for client i𝑖i to mitigate the primal residual.

Finally, the iterative steps of FedADMM with an adaptive βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} are given by

uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle u_{i}^{k+1} ≈arg⁡minui∈ℝn⁡Lβik​(ui,λik,zk),∀i∈[m],formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝐿superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle\approx\arg\min_{u_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}L_{\beta_{i}^{k}}\left(u_{i},\lambda_{i}^{k},z^{k}\right),\forall i\in[m], (3.16a)
λik+1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle\lambda_{i}^{k+1} =λik−βik​(uik+1−zk),∀i∈[m],formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscript𝑧𝑘for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\displaystyle=\lambda_{i}^{k}-\beta_{i}^{k}\left(u_{i}^{k+1}-z^{k}\right),\forall i\in[m], (3.16b)
zk+1superscript𝑧𝑘1\displaystyle z^{k+1} =arg⁡minz∈ℝn⁡Lα,βk​(uk+1,λk+1,z)+δ2​∑i=1mαi​βik​‖z−zk‖2.absentsubscript𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝐿𝛼superscript𝛽𝑘superscript𝑢𝑘1superscript𝜆𝑘1𝑧𝛿2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘superscriptnorm𝑧superscript𝑧𝑘2\displaystyle=\arg\min_{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\ L_{\alpha,\beta^{k}}\left(u^{k+1},\lambda^{k+1},z\right)+\frac{\delta}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}^{k}\|z-z^{k}\|^{2}. (3.16c)
Compatibility with the inexactness criterion.

We can easily extend our inexactness criterion (3.7) to make it compatible with the self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme (3.15). To accomplish this, we simply replace the fixed βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} with the adaptive βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} in (3.8). Then, for each client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], at the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-th communication round, it computes uik+1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1u_{i}^{k+1} such that

‖eik​(uik+1)‖≤σik​‖eik​(uik)‖,normsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑘normsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘\left\|e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k+1})\right\|\leq\sigma_{i}^{k}\left\|e_{i}^{k}(u_{i}^{k})\right\|, (3.17)

where σiksuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑘\sigma_{i}^{k} is a given constant satisfying

0<σik<22+β~ik<1,0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑘22superscriptsubscript~𝛽𝑖𝑘10<\sigma_{i}^{k}<\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{\tilde{\beta}_{i}^{k}}}<1, (3.18)

and β~ik=βik/cisuperscriptsubscript~𝛽𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘subscript𝑐𝑖\tilde{\beta}_{i}^{k}={\beta_{i}^{k}}/{c_{i}} can be independently evaluated by each client i𝑖i based on its unique situation. Hence, the inexactness criterion (3.17) with the self-adaptive penalty parameter scheme can also be executed autonomously by each client during iterations. Moreover, this allows clients to perform personalized local update steps based on their distinct data and computational resources, effectively mitigating the risk of the straggler effect.

FedADMM-InSa: An inexact and self-adaptive FedADMM.

Based on the discussions above, we propose the FedADMM-InSa algorithm using an adaptive penalty parameter βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} and present it in Algorithm 3. It brings more difficulty to prove the convergence of Algorithm 3 with a varying βiksuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑘\beta_{i}^{k} in each iteration, however, the numerical experiments in Section 4 empirically validate its robustness and improved performance.

4 Experimental Results

In this section, we conduct extensive numerical tests to demonstrate the improved performance of our proposed FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) and FedADMM-InSa (Algorithm 3) in comparison to the vanilla FedADMM (Algorithm 1). We first introduce the experimental settings and the implementation details used in our experiments. Then, we present the simulation results and analysis.

4.1 Setups

Example 1: Linear regression with a synthetic dataset.

In this example, we set each client’s local loss function to be

fi​(ui)=12​Ni​∑j=1Ni(ui⊤​aij−bij)2+γi2​‖ui‖2,i∈[m].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖12subscript𝑁𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖topsuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑗2subscript𝛾𝑖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑢𝑖2𝑖delimited-[]𝑚f_{i}(u_{i})=\frac{1}{2N_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{i}}\left(u_{i}^{\top}a_{i}^{j}-b_{i}^{j}\right)^{2}+\frac{\gamma_{i}}{2}\|u_{i}\|^{2},\quad i\in[m]. (4.1)

Here, aij∈ℝnasuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑎a_{i}^{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{a}} and bij∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑗ℝb_{i}^{j}\in\mathbb{R} are the j𝑗j-th data of client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} is the volume of data of client i𝑖i, and we denote N=∑i=1mNi𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑁𝑖N=\sum_{i=1}^{m}N_{i}. Let ⌈⋅⌉⋅\lceil\cdot\rceil be the ceiling function, i.e., ⌈x⌉𝑥\lceil x\rceil is the smallest integer not smaller than x𝑥x, e.g., ⌈1.5⌉=21.52\lceil 1.5\rceil=2. Then, following the setup in [42], we generate ⌈N/3⌉𝑁3\lceil N/3\rceil samples from the standard normal distribution, ⌈N/3⌉𝑁3\lceil N/3\rceil samples from the Student’s t𝑡t distribution with degree 5, and N−2​⌈N/3⌉𝑁2𝑁3N-2\lceil N/3\rceil samples from the uniform distribution in [−5,5]55[-5,5]. In the tests of Example 1, we set na=1,000subscript𝑛𝑎1000n_{a}=1,000, m=100𝑚100m=100, N=10,000𝑁10000N=10,000, and γi=1subscript𝛾𝑖1\gamma_{i}=1, ∀i∈[m]for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\forall i\in[m].

Example 2: Image classification with the MNIST dataset.

In the second example, we address the image classification problem using fully-connected neural networks with the MNIST dataset [20]. The MNIST dataset contains images of handwritten digits. The samples in this dataset are 28×28282828\times 28 grayscale images with handwritten digits from 0 to 9 in the center. We select a training set of 10,000 examples and a test set of 1,000 examples. The number of clients is set to m=100𝑚100m=100. For the neural networks, each client uses a fully-connected neural network with two hidden layers, each comprising 200 neurons, incorporating the cross-entropy loss and the ReLU activation function.

Non-IID data separation.

To test the performance of the algorithms on non-IID data, we separate datasets in the following way. In both examples, there are in total N=10,000𝑁10000N=10,000 training samples and m=100𝑚100m=100 clients. In Example 1, we first shuffle the training samples and then distribute them evenly among all clients. In Example 2, we first sorted the data by labels and then divided them into several shards, each shard containing images with the same label. Then, for 100 clients, the training dataset with 10,000 samples is divided into 200 shards of size 50, and each client receives 2 shards. This means each client has at most two kinds of labels in their dataset, corresponding to a pathological non-IID scenario.

FL training parameters.

In each communication round, the server uniformly samples 10% of the clients to perform the local training. During the local training, the selected clients use full-batch gradient descent with a learning rate of 0.01. For the vanilla FedADMM algorithm, unless otherwise indicated, the clients perform fixed E=10𝐸10E=10 steps of the full-batch gradient descent. For FedADMM-In and FedADMM-InSa algorithms, the number of the full-batch gradient descent steps is controlled by the inexactness criterion, and we constrain the maximum number of gradient descent steps in each communication round to 10. For the inexactness criterion, we set β~isubscript~𝛽𝑖\tilde{\beta}_{i} to the same value as βisubscript𝛽𝑖{\beta_{i}} and replace uiksuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘u_{i}^{k} with zksuperscript𝑧𝑘z^{k} for all the tests. We use the weight coefficient αi=0.01subscript𝛼𝑖0.01\alpha_{i}=0.01 because the amount of data per client is the same in both examples. We choose δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01 for the server aggregation. Finally, important parameters used in the tests are summarized in Table 1.

4.2 Evaluation of FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) with Example 1

In this subsection, we present the comparison results of our FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) and the vanilla FedADMM (Algorithm 1) with Example 1. The results are plotted in Figure 1.

In this experiment, we test scenarios with βi=1subscript𝛽𝑖1\beta_{i}=1 and βi=2subscript𝛽𝑖2\beta_{i}=2. In the case of βi=2subscript𝛽𝑖2\beta_{i}=2, as shown in Figure 1(a), FedADMM-In achieves lower loss values from the beginning and maintains this advantage throughout the experiment. For βi=1subscript𝛽𝑖1\beta_{i}=1, although FedADMM-In initially exhibits a slower loss decline than FedADMM, it reaches a similar loss value to FedADMM after about 30 rounds. Meanwhile, as illustrated in Figure 1(b) and Figure 1(c), FedADMM-In requires significantly fewer local gradient descent steps than FedADMM. These results indicate that our proposed FedADMM-In algorithm can achieve comparable or even superior training outcomes while reducing the computational load on clients.

4.3 Evaluation of FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) with Example 2

In this subsection, we conduct the comparison tests between our FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) and the vanilla FedADMM (Algorithm 1) with Example 2 and present the results in Figure 2.

In both sets of experiments conducted with penalty parameters βi=1subscript𝛽𝑖1\beta_{i}=1 and βi=2subscript𝛽𝑖2\beta_{i}=2, our proposed FedADMM-In consistently demonstrates superior performance. This is evidenced by achieving higher prediction accuracy and lower loss after the same 200 communication rounds, as illustrated in Figure 2(a) and Figure 2(b), respectively.

Additionally, we visualize the number of local gradient descent steps performed by a specific client (client 1) in each communication round, represented in Figure 2(c) and Figure 2(d). It is evident that employing our proposed FedADMM-In algorithm allows clients to execute fewer gradient descent steps as well as ensure training efficiency. This significantly reduces the potential waste of valuable computational resources in FL.

However, it is noteworthy from Figure 2 that when βi=2subscript𝛽𝑖2\beta_{i}=2, the performance of both algorithms deteriorates compared to the case of βi=1subscript𝛽𝑖1\beta_{i}=1. This discrepancy reflects the substantial impact of the initial pre-selected penalty parameters on the training performance. To address this issue, we propose the FedADMM-InSa algorithm, the performance of which is validated in the next subsection.

4.4 Evaluation of FedADMM-InSa (Algorithm 3) with Example 2

In this subsection, we present the comparison results of our FedADMM-InSa (Algorithm 3) with the other two algorithms, namely our FedADMM-In (Algorithm 2) and the vanilla FedADMM (Algorithm 1). For FedADMM-InSa, we set the initial penalty parameter βi0=2superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖02\beta_{i}^{0}=2 and update it by the scheme (3.15) with μ=20𝜇20\mu=20 and τ=2𝜏2\tau=2. For both FedADMM-In and FedADMM, the penalty parameter βi=2subscript𝛽𝑖2\beta_{i}=2 is fixed throughout the training. For the vanilla FedADMM, we test it with three different local full-batch gradient descent steps, i.e., E=2,5,10𝐸2510E=2,5,10. The results are plotted in Figure 3 and summarized in Table 2.

From Figure 3, it is evident that our FedADMM-InSa algorithm, incorporating a self-adaptive penalty parameter (3.15), significantly outperforms the other two algorithms. As depicted in Figure 3(a), under the same number of communication rounds, FedADMM-InSa exhibits significantly higher prediction accuracy compared to the other two algorithms. In other words, FedADMM-InSa can achieve a given target accuracy with fewer communication rounds than the other two algorithms. This is also validated by the fastest decreasing training loss of FedADMM-InSa shown in Figure 3(b).

Figure 3(d) illustrates that for a specific client (client 1), when using FedADMM-InSa, it performs less number of gradient descent steps compared with FedADMM-In and FedADMM (E=10𝐸10E=10), especially in the later communication rounds. This reduction in gradient descent steps is further quantified in Table 2, where compared to the baseline FedADMM (E=10𝐸10E=10) algorithm, our proposed FedADMM-In and FedADMM-InSa algorithms reduce the number of gradient descent steps by 49.8% and 64.3%, respectively, leading to a substantial improvement in training efficiency. Although FedADMM (E=2𝐸2E=2) has the lowest total number of local gradient descent steps, the value of E𝐸E has to be chosen empirically in advance. Without knowing the empirical information of the FL system, it is difficult to find an appropriate E𝐸E in advance. Meanwhile, the decline in test accuracy from FedADMM (E=2𝐸2E=2) to FedADMM (E=10𝐸10E=10) is likely attributed to the pathological non-IID datasets, further emphasizing the challenge of empirically choosing an appropriate E𝐸E in advance. Notably, our proposed FedADMM-InSa algorithm outperforms FedADMM (E=2𝐸2E=2) in terms of test accuracy, achieving a balance between improving training performance and reducing computational load.

Finally, in Figure 3(c), the variation of the average penalty parameter across all clients is plotted. It can be observed that FedADMM-InSa dynamically adjusts the average penalty parameter from an initial value of two to around one. This demonstrates that FedADMM-InSa can adaptively correct the initially improperly chosen penalty parameters, highlighting the robustness of our proposed algorithm.

5 Conclusions

In this paper, we introduce the FedADMM-InSa algorithm, a novel approach that leverages the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) to address the challenges of federated learning (FL) in the presence of data and system heterogeneity. Distinguished from current FedADMM methods, our inexact and self-adaptive algorithm mitigates the need for intricate empirical hyperparameter settings. The introduced inexactness criterion improves computational efficiency by removing the requirement to determine local training accuracy in advance. Additionally, the self-adaptive scheme dynamically adjusts each client’s penalty parameter, enhancing the robustness of our algorithm. Numerical tests demonstrate the reduction in clients’ local computational load and accelerated learning performance on both synthetic and real-world datasets, highlighting the practical advancements our approach brings to FL systems. In addition to the demonstrated benefits of our proposed algorithm, the integration of privacy-preserving techniques and the investigation of the algorithm’s performance in large-scale FL applications are interesting and challenging future directions.

On the right-hand side of (A.11), the three quadratic terms are easily amenable to manipulation across various indicators through algebraic operations. However, it is less apparent how the cross-term can be controlled to demonstrate the convergence of the sequence {wk}superscript𝑤𝑘\{w^{k}\}. Therefore, we study this term and demonstrate that the sum of these cross-terms over K≥1𝐾1K\geq 1 iterations can be bounded by certain quadratic terms. Note that uik⟶k→∞ui∗,uik−zk⟶k→∞0formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘superscript𝑧𝑘0u_{i}^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}u_{i}^{*},u_{i}^{k}-z^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0, eik​(uk+1)⟶k→∞0superscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘superscript𝑢𝑘10e_{i}^{k}\left(u^{k+1}\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0, and the gradient of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is Lipschitz continuous (see 3.1), we have

λik⟶k→∞λi∗,∀i∈[m].formulae-sequencesuperscript⟶→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\lambda_{i}^{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\rightarrow\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}\lambda_{i}^{*},\quad\forall i\in[m]. (A.44)

We thus complete the proof. ∎
